review.title: “WK finding its footing and confidence”

review.title: “Good place to work but large company that doesn't understand all their businesses”

review.cons: Cons – Too large of a company and doesn't understand all their divisions problems and even how they do business. Eliminated my position when there was a lot of opportunity to expand in other areas.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Sell off some non-core business

review.title: “Excellent Company - in the past. Now, not so much...”
review.pros: Pros – Large company with great benefits; they also go by the rules of The Netherlands - which is their HQ. SO, no drug tests for example.
review.cons: Cons – The current group of folks that pass for recruiters are bumbling & incompetent. There is a lot of nepotism and friends getting hired. When a job opening occurs, they interview 10 people - to satisfy some requirement - and then hire their friend or cousin instead. I end up working with these (unqualified) employees.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Hire back some of the well experienced folks that were let go over all of the reorganizations of the last 5 years. I have referred excellent (laid off) employees - only to be rebuffed. I do not want the referral bonus, I want the positions filled by those that did them so well over the years.

review.title: “Technical Support Representative”

The customer service call center that I worked in had the best team. Although most of the employees I worked with are not there, the Team Leader who shall remain anonymous, was super nice, but firm enough to get your butt into shape.
review.cons: Cons – None that I can think of.
review.advice-to-management: Yes, I would recommend this company to a friend – I'm optimistic about the outlook for this company

review.title: “Not a bad place to work for depending in what business unit you work in.”

review.cons: Cons – Education reimbursement is up to your department not a company benefitPay is average to low
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Need to drill down to middle management and workers to get a real sense of how things are going.

review.title: “Struggling to change, but with legacy management tools”
review.pros: Pros – Wolters Kluwer has a large pool of talented people. The culture is collaborative within groups. The defined corporate strategy is sensible: moving up the value chain with clients, by embedding content within clients workflow processes.
review.cons: Cons – Budget constraints & concerns flavor all human resource planning. Human resource support is basic, but getting better. Difficult to get approvals for creation of new positions, either to provide room for promotions, or to hire necessary additional support positions.The company is also hampered by silos of technology and of processes - with poor tools and little cultural support for breaking down silos and barriers to collaboration across groups.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Wolters Kluwer needs to examine its existing groups & decide where levels of investment need to be made not just based upon a profitability/growth spectrum, but also based upon potential profitability/growth. The lack of investment in talent, technology and organizational change in existing groups that don't meet p/g targets leads to a cycle where change can't be effectively implemented.

review.title: “Not what it use to be...”
review.pros: Pros – Decent Salary. Good Benefits. Many very knowledgeable employees with a ton of experience.
review.cons: Cons – No room for advancement or even lateral movement. Constant lay-offs. Very cliquish ... if you aren't part of a particular group, your days are numbered. Entire departments are being elimnated, yet the manager remains (who are they managing?). No H.R. support -- will back the Managers no matter what. Apathetic employees.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Listen to employees complaints and take them seriously. Abandon the "if you don't like it then leave" attitude. Instead of bring in new excutives/managers from the outside, try hiring from within.

review.title: “I had a positive experience working here.”

review.recommended: – I'm optimistic about the outlook for this company

review.title: “A lot of work, but worth the effort”

review.cons: Cons – Upper management doesn't really seem to understand the market any more. Too many shifting priorities as executives have changed several times over the last couple of years.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Don't be shy to spend money to bring the products where they need to be. We are falling behind the competition, and it shows - both in the maturity of the suite and in the amount of customer churn. Listen to your product managers as they understand the market better than anyone. Build products that delight its users. Customers pays a premium for CCH products - please reinvest that money in the products.

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Hard to advise upper management when there was none present. I think WK in general is probably a good company. The division of my subsidiary was just not right for me for the long haul. I'd work for WK again.

Multiply that by dozens of emails a day, and it's no wonder you can easily work 12-15 hour days just managing the paperwork. It's exhausting and endless. The down-side is management thinks there is nothing wrong with bombarding the account managers with daily doses of admin, reports for reports and more reports to report on those reports! It's like being in a hamster tread-mill of paperwork. Management however still demands that you make your quota and get into the field to see clients regardless of the hours spent behind your PC.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Help us make more sales by removing the mundane paperwork, non-stop reporting of account activity which is really something a sales admin department should be doing and please, please consolidate and update your PC systems so we can all be more efficient at our jobs.

review.title: “Dead cats don't bounce”
review.pros: Pros – This once great company has a rich legacy of products, a strong brand, and a few really talented people who have a deep understanding of tax and accounting professional needs.Much needed changes has been introduced along with a new executive team. The change is good - the team and processes they bring - less so.
review.cons: Cons – -Executive team micromanages the portfolio and costs.-Great at making plans - but then cutting expenses needed to support those plans and yet hold revenue targets. Then have senior executives look at you as if your surprising them when you can't make the revenue targets you attempt to pull back on.-Leaders who think they understand the customer because they understand the process of gaining customer insights. Gone for the most part are people who have actually worked in accounting and tax firms and/or studies tax and accounting from management. So even the most basic observations about markets need to be explained over and over to key executives.-Almost all knowledgeable product managers are gone - so the people who understood why products were built and how they fit in with the portfolio workflow are not there to help the new executives understand the nuances.-recent disasters at CCH Small Firm Services around recent tax prep product launch (due to overly aggressive product introduction goals) have irreparably damaged CCH reputation in this segment of the market. Choice of executives without experience or relationship with the target market will result in hampering any hope of recovering share in the near future.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Excessive controls and micromanaging is turning the limited talent into power point assemblers, rubber stampers, and totally unempowered. Risk taking and innovation by those who truly know the customer is down considerable. New management team constantly marginalizes any different perspectives by forcing all decisions thru an internal spanking machine where it's easy to criticize but hard to champion anything new. Stop designing systems and processes that thwart entrepreneurial spirit or the business will wither and die all too soon...

review.title: “A slowly sinking ship”
review.pros: Pros – Because of the industry there is a good job security as long as you are capable of doing your job.There are some truly good people here.
review.cons: Cons – Middle management of late has very little concept of employee satisfaction or modern business principles when it comes to management. It often times feels like this company is stuck in the '80s.Lower rung employees are seen as a liability to the company rather than an asset, which leads to anti-employee sentiment from management from many of the management team.Salary and benefits are maintained at a "just barely enough" level to keep employees from jumping ship.Raises are scarce and infrequent, in the name of profitability.Poor management decisions on how to handle product development which lead to poor product performance are often times blamed on lower level employees.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Take a note from the companies who are at the top of the lists rather than whatever the latest corporate self-help book you picked up. Realize that your employees at the lowest level are the some of the most important, particularly those who work directly with customers.CCH is one of the lowest rated companies in the country for employee satisfaction and it only continues to get worse. It is hemorrhaging talent and getting an infusion of "lowest bidder" replacement warm bodies. This is going to lead to the destruction of the excellent reputation the company has with it's customers which in turn is going to lead to dropping profits.This isn't the '80s, times have changed, and successful companies have realized that a happy workforce is a productive workforce.

review.title: “Beware of false promises”

Its a job, but THATS IT. Most people in management positions were hired as managers. Its almost never that you hear someone has worked their way up in the company. Its sad when there are open management positions and employees aren't interested in them. Its even worse when most managers leave or drop down in position b/c the company is so unfair.

review.title: “About as good as you can expect right now”
review.pros: Pros – Long standing brand (100 years) and marketplace position. Some really good people work here. Friendly Chicago offices. This company is more respectful towards older workers, which, as a younger worker, I really respect. It might be one of the last companies out there that appear to actually makes an attempt to retain aging mid-level workers who have been loyal after many years of service. I'm giving it 3 stars on a because I know how it stacks up against other opportunities in the marketplace. I believe there are only a handful of 4 star companies out there, and so this is pretty much as good as it gets right now (which I don't think is good at all). There are some forward thinking strategies, some are misguided though. My impression is the CEO of Wolters Kluwer (not CCH, the sub - she is new so I have no opinion yet) is a forward thinker and she takes a balanced and rational approach to company strategy. She does not come across as the tyrannical type that head up so many other companies right now.
review.cons: Cons – Just like every other massive company out there there are never ending unrealistic expectations of perpetual growth. Mysterious faceless executives make sweeping changes and crony based promotions abound as they do in every other company in America. This company is based out of the Netherlands, and the US branch is held much higher profit and efficiency standards. The US has much lower benefits than their European counterparts. The whole idea that I should in-debt myself to the banks for 30 years, give half my earnings to the gov't, take a brief 1 week vacation, and then enslave myself to a corporation just so I can live hand to mouth until the day I die really does not appeal to me.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – You need more flexible pricing strategies to secure revenue streams over longer periods. The marketplace is volatile and we are losing customers we could otherwise retain. You need to allow for more creative solutions. Sales people are extremely important to the lifeblood of your business, and and the current model does not empower us enough. Encourage process worker b's to think outside the box and solve problems creatively without just going back to the rule book or having to talk to management. We have some people who are really stuck in rigid processes and it slows sales down to a crawl sometimes. Overall I think CCH is one of the better companies out there, but there is not nearly enough transparency in management. As every corporation does, you still have serious problems with nepotism. Man-up/Woman-up management-and squash this! You'll earn a lot of respect for it. Tell your buddies to go get another job at another company (you can give them a stellar recommendation still) and make new friends at the water cooler-they will make out ok. Every worker in America is tired of the same old routine and we will reach a breaking point, I promise. A good start to changing things would be to start enforcing mandatory vacation (don't forget to include sales) as your European counterparts do. That would be a nice change and forward thinking. Nothing worse than having vacation and not being able to actually use it - it is a bait and switch routine and we are all tired of this.

Because there is a never ending need for employees to work overtime, needless to say you aren't leaving at 5:00 or even 6:00, you get the picture. Depending on the length of your commute, arriving home at 8 or 9:00 or even later on a fairly regular basis is a way of life. If you have commitments in the evening (family, children, school) they'd better be understanding of your crazy schedule. Upper management realizes all of this is a big problem and the strain it puts on their employees, however there is little they can do about it, as employees leave or are let go, replenishing the head count is difficult. A long training process is involved and typically takes 6 months to a year for a new hire Researcher to get up to speed. Also, one of every four people hired do not pan out others become dissatisfied with the position and the demands it makes on one's life and decide to hang it up. So there is lots of one step forward two steps back kind if thing going on. To their credit management has taken steps to make the training shorter and make it a more pleasant place to work, alleviating some of the strain on the current group, but all of this is moving at a glacial pace.Negativity galore. The previous poster is correct, you'll be told every way conceivable on how you screwed up, while part of this is necessary, there is little or no positive enforcement. And the draconian and at times subjective point scoring system doesn't help. If you want to feel like you are back in Jr. high, then you won't mind this.

review.title: “Understaffed, overworked, unappreciated - CT has it all!”
review.pros: Pros – You can't beat the PTO - 4 weeks to start + 3-4 optional days a year; increases to 5 and 6 weeks after 5 and 10 years, respectively. 35 hour work week, good benefits package (health is great, dental is lacking), casual dress, and great co-workers, for the most part.
review.cons: Cons – Everything else. The job itself is grossly misrepresented during the interview process. The 35 hour work week is wonderful in theory, but employees typically exceed 40 thanks to offices being understaffed. There are plenty of employees who have been around for 10+ years, but turnover is high amongst new, college educated employees who have little incentive to stick around once they realize what they've stepped into, and that the "multitude" of advancement opportunities they were promised when applying for the job simply aren't available to them; you should expect to remain in your entry level position for five years (minimum), regardless of job performance. Once you've passed the five year mark, ensure that you aren't TOO good at your job, as you might be deemed too valuable to a department and blocked from advancing elsewhere. Management, from the top down, is inept and has no interest in hearing any ideas that fall outside of their own narrow view. The company's idea of "employee development" is forcing them to take at least 4 online courses - glorified power point presentations - a year, most of which on subjects that relate little, if at all, to your actual employment goals.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Reward your employees where it counts: their pockets. Miniscule raises and consistently decreasing bonuses when the company is clearly profiting are little incentive to keep educated employees from looking elsewhere.

If you voice any concern you are on the black ball list and will never go anywhere in the company. HR sides with management at ALL times, no exceptions. Little to no trust for management team. Management team and if they don't like you and your not in the "in" crowd - expect to go no where. Very little respect between managers and employees. Your spoken to in a condense ding, belittling manor.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Listen to feedback from employees about their managers, stop the intimidation in the office where employees fear to speak the truth due to retaliation or being demoted and made an example in front of the entire company.

Change happens incredibly slowly for all the reasons previously state.

Since many of their customers provide diversified financial services, a customer might have WKFS sales reps from multiple teams competing against one another to sell similar products into the same account. Their risk product suite includes an audit solution that is actually sold and supported by a totally separate business division. That product also competes directly with the Axentis solution, which is sold by another WK company under the same brand name. This is all very confusing to potential customers. WKFS derives most of its revenues from the sale of regulatory content so many of its managers come from legal and government backgrounds, and this results in an organization that is stagnant, slow-moving, and generally unresponsive to market changes.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – While you are busy holding conference calls and drafting memos, large competitors like Thomson Reuters (and several very aggressive small startups) are stealing your accounts at an alarming rate. Management needs to be more responsive to the dynamic nature of the compliance market, and to its customers' needs.

review.title: “Terrible Leadership”

review.title: “A Good place to work for professional growth.”

review.cons: Cons – Poor communication between development and operations for software requirements.Bureaucracy can lead to a lot of red-tape in terms of getting things done. This leads to a lot of lost productivity.

review.title: “Terrific Company Once-Upon-a-Time...but Not Anymore”

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Think before you make decisions across the board.

review.title: “It is a great place to work overall.”

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Take a closer look at certain clicks and start from the top down either reorganizing or laying off employees.

review.title: “Great peers & immediate managers, but poor direction at the top.”

They are still struggling launch an SAP implementation thats taking forever and costing millions. There is always excitement for some new project then the business loses interest.Almost no techncial IT training is given anymore.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Settle down, take a deep breath and relax. Go back to the development pool concept and quit farming out jobs to India. CCH was rock solid because of its teams in Chicago and Cedar Rapids - not India.

review.title: “Poorly managed company with a terrible work atmosphere”

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I would probably say the most valuable piece of advice would be to get a better understanding of why customers are leaving and to also modernize the company with new staff and maybe training for existing staff to get up to date.

review.title: “Frustrating and unfulfilling”

review.cons: Cons – Senior Management are spineless and have zero leadership skills. Poor salary.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Get your head out of your ass.

review.title: “Love my job”

review.cons: Cons – Commute sucks but the environment is worth it. Sometime a lack of connect between departments.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the communication and thanks for all the great benefits.

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Hire more competent people.

review.title: “Executive team works in a silo”

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Somehow upper management forgets that LWW publishes books! Yes, the market dynamics are changing but don't forget what pays the bills!

review.title: “Needing a boost on focusing on fundamentals”

review.cons: Cons – A lot of management-by-default instead of decisiveness. Management has a tendency to involve itself too deeply in daily tasking (tactical) rather than training, developing and nurturing the resource talent to allow them to take on the truly big picture (strategic) vision for moving ahead and innovating.Concentration is on creating then putting out fires rather than smooth and organized processes that will prevent fires. It creates a rather herky-jerky (often counterproductive) work environment that is way overstressed when compared to productivity levels.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – "Forward Progress" is not always good; be willing to retreat from bad decisions.When measuring and acknowledging success give credit to those who accomplished it rather than only the manager; when measuring and remonstrating for failure, include management. You also need to hold manager accountable and require commitments; them committing other people does not count, they must commit themselves and the resources (personnel, physical, and physical) they are tasked with.Provide adequate (even minimal) training; saying that a resource will “pick it up as they go” is insufficient.You must measure performance against the job description into which people are hired.Provide succession planning and career path guidance.Temp to hire positions should be honored; hire your temps on when headcount opens instead of keeping a temp on and then hire someone else to fill the headcount. If they are good enough to keep, they are good enough to hire.

review.title: “Content provider that wants to be an innovative software developer but has no clue how to do it”
review.pros: Pros – Very deep expertise in several lines of businessVery little micro management - employees encouraged to take ownership and accountabilityGood work life balanceOn the whole, good people who know their customers wellAdvancement opportunities if motivated to do so
review.cons: Cons – -Insanely little collaboration among business units. The company is a collection of acquisitions of legacy businesses. Each of these businesses may as well be it's own company with it's own CEO. Good luck executing on a product roadmap, multiple delayed or cancelled dev projects because of a lack of vision in deployment and management of dev resources. At company meeting, he told entire company "if you don't like your job find a new one...". Many people listened to that advice.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – In order to truly create innovative, problem solving solutions, invest in high quality in house development.

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Go visit some of your largest customers and really understand their needs before making decisions.

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – I'd request that management improve their benefits. It's pretty terrible and non-existent for the bevy of 'temps' they hire. Offer more training courses for excel, etc.

review.title: “Meat Grinder for College Graduates”
review.pros: Pros – Paid overtime and decent quarterly bonuses mean compensation is good for an entry level position.Decent experience developing professional skills.401K and health insurance package.
review.cons: Cons – The amount of time you are expected to work is punishing. In the Trademark Research you will routinely work 50-60 hour weeks and sometimes even more than that. You will eat lunch at you desk while you work because while technically you are given a half hour lunch there will be no time for it. Because of this, turnover is huge and management only maintains a staff as small as it possibly can. As a result, you are perpetually understaffed, perpetually overworked, and with no hope of it changing beyond advancing to a management position where they are actually able to leave at 5 most of the days of the week.99% of the feedback you will get for your work is negative. Your performance is a points-based system that you, essentially, only can lose points from. In addition the manager of the Quality Assurance team seems to enjoy humiliating researchers who have made mistakes and is extremely condescending.I could have dealt with one of these things, but not both. It ends up being an abusive environment.If you work for CT, save up all the money you will get from overtime, and start looking for a new job the moment you walk in the door and don't stop until you've found something.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Overstaff. Turnover is so high and the training period is so long that you need to overhire in order for current employees to feel any effect. If this results in not enough work to go around, then let employees voluntarily go home early. The current situation where they staff is eternally overworked will eventually spiral out of control when too many of your employees leave at once, and then your business will collapse because there is nobody to do the work.

review.title: “Salary is okay, but expectations and work load not”

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – It's kind of pointless to give advice because as a master plan is filtered down from below and you are just expected to accomplish it. There really is no room for discussion. I was on one advisory panel that was geared towards bringing issues from workers to upper management, which was disbanded after six months.

review.cons: Cons – - Affter acquisition main headquarters was distant from child company. - Took a long time to get approvals because of long processes - Employees with most experience and talents were not recognized - No room for growth
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – When you make a company acquisition, make sure you find out who has experience, longevity and knowledge in the company and make use that talent. It seems that the company was not aware of the most valuable employees and allowed them to leave without finding a way to keep them. review.title: “Run, Don't Walk Away from this Place”

review.cons: Cons – The management is so bad at this place, it has a reputation of being toxic. So many colleagues would sit at their desks in tears for all the impossible workload given to them by upper management. The company's idea of making a profit is to cut people instead of investigating in the infrastructure necessary to transform from the print to the online space. The so out of touch decisions that management would make were nonsensical to those who they would ask to implement them. Horrible environment to work in.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Start investing in the infrastructure needed to succeed in the online space instead of just talking about it and starting and then stopping projects that go nowhere. Stop laying off people and asking the remaining employees to shoulder the burden of work--they're already at maximum capacity. Get rid of the incompetent managers who know nothing about publishing!

review.title: “An OK place to kill time while waiting for the Right Job to come through”

review.cons: Cons – Salaries are dreadful. Depending which group you work with, constant intense stress can be expected, or you may have problems filling your day. Zero personal development, almost zero growth potential. Most management personnel are arrogant, disrespectful, and blissfully unaware of what it means to produce what they are asking. Huge problems are simply tolerated and walked around, like the elephant in the room, because managers don't know how to solve problems...they apparently excel at Excel, and little else.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Recognize that the ones in the trenches matter for more than their output. Consider an advancement policy that's more than a popularity contest. Eradicate the offensive culture of arrogance that permeates the management levels.

review.cons: Cons – Internal Computer systems are arduoussome of the support reps are clueless, although knowledgeable.90% of Managers are solid A players, the 10% factor is in play.

review.title: “Employees pay personal price for poor management planning”

review.cons: Cons – CCH is caught between an old industrial way of thinking (very top-down management) and the new guard who want "employee empowerment." So, if you show initiative, the first group will get angry at you for usurping their authority, and if you don't show initiative, the second group will say you're not adding value to the team.The company makes software, but is very behind the times technologically. Young hot shots who were brought in from other companies to try to modernize things all leave within a short period of time out of frustration.The company has bloated management that is poorly trained. The company doesn't pay enough to draw top talent, so even the high performing employees are only average compared to other places I've worked.Morale is very poor, mostly because the rank-and-file employees have a lot of responsibility without much control over their circumstances. The ridiculous amount of overtime hours has stopped in recent years because the economy is tight and the company has been affected by it -- so, basically, it stopped because they didn't want to pay it -- but the amount of work has not decreased. Recent reductions in force have made the amount of work worse.Most employees have very little flexibility about when/how/where they work. It's very much a "stay at your desk and work" environment.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Get rid of the leads and managers who are only paying lip service to the high-performing teams initiative, without really believing/participating in it.Pay for top talent, and then DEVELOP that top talent to be good leaders.Stop implementing a new management philosophy every year. No one takes any of these new ideas seriously because we know next year you'll come up with something new.

review.title: “Glad It's Over”
review.pros: Pros – Benefits are great including 20 days of PTO plus 13 paid holidays. Company has been actively remodeling the Peterson location from it's 1950ies appearance.
review.cons: Cons – Oh where to begin... I'm not sure how the inside sales department was originally thought up, but by the time I left it had become a place that people were obviously miserable walking into each day. The director of my group came from a collections department at a major credit card/banking operation and undoubtedly lacked a through knowledge of how to effectively motivate the sales teams. Instead the mentality of success followed those of a telemarketing set up, ie. high # of dials, monitoring of employee activities, and fake appreciation of a job well done. I want to mention that many on my team never approached management with recommendations/suggestions because we weren't take seriously or it would be used against us as why things are the way they are (based on a few people who had taken that initiative)The leads we called were routinely duplicated and assigned to multiple reps to call upon, and many times were also dead leads (literally dead people). There was virtually no marketing of our product to potential customers, barely any partnership with state bar associations or other groups, and we were dominated by every single competitor in the industry as a result. Sales were incredibly tough to achieve and you were definitely lucky if the customer didn't cancel in the 12 month cancellation window, otherwise it would go against your sales quota & commissions. Quite a few on my team were in constant worry of being put on a performance plan, which didn't help the morale whatsoever.Additionally, there was definitely a feeling that my department didn't matter in the larger scheme of Wolters Kluwer considering division meetings rarely mentioned our team vs. the other departments within our division. Also worth mentioning is the "sales trainer" has no sales background either which hinders their understanding of what challenges the team faced every single day.

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Debrief employees who are leaving. Take the time to live with products to see what is "intuitive." Inside knowledge regarding what US professionals need requires staff living in the US. Avoid cultural arrogance. review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Please consider what made CCH a leader in the marketplace in past years. I know the economy is tough but customers still need to receive a good product.

review.title: “Strong company core competency, Weaker company Vision for Role”
review.pros: Pros – Great people that like to have fun while getting work accomplished. Strong confident position in the market place at the Tier 1 Accounting space. Management appreciates it's people and is willing to work hard and long in order to be successful. If you are willing to do the same you will fit right in. CCH is a large organization but the accounting technology group operates like it's own start up...with cash. The players are a good team of individuals that have been around for a while and they like to work hard as well as play hard.Compensation was on the short side of preferable but great benefits, good training, great corporate events and outstanding people. All interact if you make it so from the president of the division on down.
review.cons: Cons – This role was developed to bring smaller market accounting firms into the fold and management was admittedly unclear on what the demographic for this role would be. Guesses were ranged from firms with 1 to firms with 125 professionals. Given CCH strong 98% market penetration in the tier 1 accounting space the cash cow was going away. This was a technology position and management didn't seem certain on exactly how to go about pursuing the small/medium market firms. Having sold a premium technology to firms that asked about price later, there was a disconnect in dealing with smaller firms.There was some minor static between the New Business people and the sales team that had been around a while -- natural nervousness due to the unknown but it was managed fairly well. Eventually this role was phased into several existing positions.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Work a little harder on understanding your new markets. review.title: “Work at CCH”
review.pros: Pros – The benefit package included 401k matching and profit sharing plan, wide range of health insurance and dental care options. Generous vacation and time off allowance though both were combined into the same pool of days. Casual office environment, sometimes too casual as sweatpants and hooded sweatshirts were allowed.
review.cons: Cons – First thing that you notice are how old and unkempt the place looks. Cubicles and carpets are old and worn, walls and doors need painting, office furniture is outdated and uncomfortable. Employee training is lacking, formal training on software and policies is fine, specifics of the jobs have to be learned from people who spent more time on the job and knowledge sharing is a real problem. Most seriously, higher management is dishonest about the goals and future direction and communications are uneven and sporadic. More worrying is utter dishonesty with which management handled process improvement, people who spent years developing and building the business were discarded like useless pieces of office furniture. Opportunities for advancements are limited, most get promoted from within by having connections and ears of sympathetic managers. Improvement to electronic infrastructure were undertaken when old systems could no longer be sufficient, getting help with computers or other office equipment required calls to outsourcers, problems often were not resolved for days.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Be honest with people, treat them as adults and not as ignorant bumpkins.

review.title: “Health Division used to be a good place to work”
review.pros: Pros – People - some have very tenured experience and are willing to share insightsBenefits - decent array of choicesSalaries - base is pretty good, some bonus plans are lacking
review.cons: Cons – Lack of clear strategyFormer pharma management lacks publishing experienceLack of loyalty for long term employeesDistrustful
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Listen to the employees, especially those with long tenure - they have the first hand experience you need to truly build the organization

review.title: “Company stuck in outdated employer-employee relations.”
review.pros: Pros – Work-life balance. Good name to have on resume. Excellent teammate relations. Four weeks PTO and great benefits.
review.cons: Cons – First of all, CCH facilities are completely outdated and gross. For a company posting profits like they are, they should be able to pump some money into their offices. Other downsides include nepotism, favoritism, and being misled on advancement opportunities. Management is absolutely most concerned about their paychecks vs. how to create a great atmosphere for their employees. A lot could be done to boost productivity, say sales contests and recognition for a job well done, but there is a serious lack of these ideas. A little goes a long way for employees who feel appreciated.Also as a sales rep with CCH, I saw plenty of sales channel conflict. Field Sales Reps are the precious babies of CCH while other sales personnel don't matter nearly as much. CCH is willing to pay FSRs a great amount of money towards their commissions, so if you're looking at outside sales, this would be a good fit. All other sales professionals in the company won't see nearly as much money.I would also say this company currently has the mentality that it's an employers market and anyone who doesn't agree can go work elsewhere. CCH could be revolutionary with it's attitude to the workforce, but it chooses to hold on to outdated ideas.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – We all realize the bottom line is most important to you, but so should your employees. Happy employees = productive employees = more revenues for you.

review.title: “The concensus-driven large-scale Holding Company model - Recipe for Madness....”
review.pros: Pros – Despite some routine upheavals common to all major corporations, it's actually a fairly stable place if you aspire to be at Director level or below. Most VP's and above get shot or otherwise attritted on a regular basis, typically 2 years, then out. The better career strategy in this place is to stay one notch lower, and stay off the radar, and then stay for many years. There is little incentive to jump to the higher levels here.
review.cons: Cons – The place is absolutely obsessed about their insane BDP's (business development plans) and budgets. They spend 9 months each year arguing what the numbers should be for the next year and initiating various cuts, instead of growing the business, grooming people and taking entrepreneurial risks. Then they start the insanity all over again 3 months later. It's a protracted disease like nothing you've ever seen anywhere, and is driven by a Dutch finance spendthrift mentality that all other companies have abandoned 50 years ago. It is not really a corporation at all, just a loose group of companies running wild, with a deep fear of any central control and fearful of any change. The few folks who are in the central control spots are fearful of exercising any power or authority for fear of losing their jobs, and tend to just go with the flow and make least common denominator decisions that offend no one.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Get some good strong leaders who make fast and powerful decisions, and then back them up. Stop rolling over to what every business unit wants and exercise some strong central control. The shared services part of the company seems like it might be uniquely positioned to run all the business units, instead of being their lapdog, and should be moved up the org chart accordingly.

review.title: “Decent company, but easy to fall into a stagnation trap”
review.pros: Pros – WKFS is a typical very large company. They pay is competitive for the area. The environment is steady, not much confusions about what your job is. A lot of maintenance work on very old products that still are doing well in the marketplace. Keep your head down, do you work and you'll be fine and get a decent paycheck. There is a decent catered in lunch everyday. The people are generally friendly. The benefits are good, they give you an above average 4 weeks of vacation from the day you start. Seemed to me to be a generally well run place.
review.cons: Cons – WKFS is a typical very large company. There are a variety of people with different skill levels who work there, but lot of them are people who are looking for their steady paycheck and have stagnated in terms of career advancement. It is very easy to get stuck in a niche job and stay there for years. Their system for evaluating employees seems to change every year. I got the sense management simply had no idea which of their employees were quality, high skilled people and which were cubicle drone dolts. A large new software development project seemed to be floundering because no one really knew its purpose.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Focus on your existing products. Eliminate new software development, or try to aggressively build a small team of high quality software people.

review.title: “Caveat employee”
review.pros: Pros – Large company, good benefits, opportunities for advancement if you change your specialty. They have worldwide offices and appeal to the highly skilled marketing person. They have a lot of little perks, like company-sponsored lunches and parties. Their health benefits are above average both in what is covered as well as out-of-pocket cost to employees. They have a fairly generous profit-sharing program, based on a percentage of annual salary. They only require a 37.5 hour workweek and pay most technical employees an annual salary. They offer 24 days of vacation (the parent company is Europe-based so they follow the European idea of lots of 'vacation' time) for new salaried employees.
review.cons: Cons – Large company doesn't really feel loyal to employees, although they expect absolute loyalty upwards. They are currently in a situation where the parent company, Wolters Kluwer, is demanding a fairly high return on investment; the last year I worked there it was 18%, which is very difficult to maintain in their market segment. They have twice (and, I understand, yet again) cut positions or, in my case, out-sourced positions to fatten the bottom line to try to meet their goals. They also do not give very much feedback to employees regarding contemplated employment changes. For example, in December I was told my job was safe, and in January it was out-sourced.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – More loyalty to employees, especially older, more experienced employees.

review.title: “Stability of a large organization meets flexability of market focused busines units - great place for change leaders!”
review.pros: Pros – Flexability and ooportunity to contribute. Wolters Kluwer is a very large orgnization, however they are strucutured into smaller market focused business unit. There are differences in culture from one business unit to the next. The financial services unit is great place to be if you are market focused and like to effect change. This unit has proiven over the past couple years that it is nimble and flexiable enough to respond to market conditions and change in ways that make the most sense for the business.
review.cons: Cons – Large organization that can be difficult to understand and navitgate at corporate level. However, consolidation fo information sources is making this easier.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – WKFS has made a lot of progress this year in creating an environment of collobration between business units, keep this up! Senior management must continue to show a high level of support as well as provide the resources needed to execute well on initiatives.

review.title: “Abandon hope all ye who enter here”
review.pros: Pros – You need a paycheck and you don't have any other options. Of course, some of the businesses are better run than others, for example, the US tax business is more successful and better run than many of the other US businesses.
review.cons: Cons – Poor management, lack of strategy, decisions based on politics not business, crumbling infrastructure, unable to innovate or execute competently on even the biggest most well-funded projects. This company is not just left behind by the competition, even our customers are innovating better and more rapidly with their own content and they are not professional information companies
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Rationalize the business, understands what customers need and what others in the market are offering, hire people who have the skills and ideas to get things done and visibly support their efforts with words, decisions and funding

review.title: “Wolters Kluwer Financial Services is the best brand you may not have heard about in the twin cities!”
review.pros: Pros – The best reason to work at Wolters Kluwer Financial Services is the ability to contribute at every level and the potential for growth.
review.cons: Cons – This is a great place to work!
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep it up!

review.title: “Good company to work for, as long as you can learn quickly”
review.pros: Pros – if you work hard and smart, you will be allowed to work from home and take time off almost anytime. Comp time is awarded for most individuals, as long as you don't abuse it.
review.cons: Cons – Winter vacations cannot possibly happen. This is a tax company, so the tax development season stretches from October to March, and can be very very hectic at times.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Listen to your employees, remember that they know what is going on. Give complements when deserving.

review.title: “Decent environment, nice freedom, but comes at a price...your salary and maybe some sanity.”
review.pros: Pros – My boss in particular, while being tough as nails, is very gracious about time off and accomodating times where errands need to be run etc... Freedom feels pretty nice.
review.cons: Cons – Pay isn't close to what the industry averages are. Centralized resources and permission are ridiculous and seem to harm productivity more than help. A whole lot of ass kissing going on.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Invest in your employees. There are some sharp people here, but there is decent turnover of these, which I'm sure is due to unrewarding pay scales.

review.title: “Meh nothing special typical corporate bs”
review.pros: Pros – Some of the benefits like lots of vacation time is very nice. Your current manager will be the key to your enjoyment working there.
review.cons: Cons – You're just a little guy there no advancement. The business moves regardless of what the pieces say
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – You can't keep giving your people a 3% raise and expect them to perform at a decent level or to continue to want to work there.

review.title: “If you want employees to like you, invest in them”
review.pros: Pros – Good benefits package.Work-life balance can be good or bad, depends on P&L you are part of.
review.cons: Cons – Numbers driven ... almost to death - not everything can be crystallized to numbers.GE-like culture - sounds good, but not something to be proud of.Employee development is nil. There is no employee training programSenior management levels have lower competency.Few people know about this coy. Fewer can pronounce its name.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Continue to earn profits, but invest in employee developmentChange the company name, no offense to W or K

review.title: “Large bureaucratic multi-national desperately figuring out how to integrate dozens of acquisitions”
review.pros: Pros – Opportunity to take ownership of customer facing products or specific product features is rewarding
review.cons: Cons – Company is understaffed, employees are overworked, turn over is high, there are no perks, recognition for effort is non existent and there are near 0 advancement opportunities. Company has been consistently cutting full time staff for past couple years so morale is in the tank. Limited to no opportunities for product innovation. Management act like dictators, keep your mouth shut or get stomped.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Show that you care about your people even a little bit, at least make an effort to build a community among the thousands of Wolters Kluwer employees to bring morale out of the crapper. WK employees never talk to each other.

review.title: “Easy to join but hard to change.”
review.pros: Pros – flexible scheduling, excellent benifits, paid time off, education options, wide variety of career options. generally friendly, cheerful workspace. high level of comaraderie and helpfullness in the middle and lower levels. upper management/leadership is willing to invest in employees and promote from within.
review.cons: Cons – large, somewhat disorganized corporate structure. general brand/marketing/structure confusion. poor top down communication. very reactive management, little long term vision. few of the top level managers have experience in the markets in which their company's product and services are sold.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Open more channels of communication between the lower sections of the corporation and management. Be less reactive and try to develop and stick to a long or at least middle term plan. be more selective in picking top level management with willingness to be proactive and actively engaged in the market and internally.

review.title: “Expecting the real meaning of job leveling”
review.pros: Pros – CCH is flexible in time if you are a full time emoloyee
review.cons: Cons – pay scale, employees at the same level gets paid differently
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – though the pay scale is less at least treat the employees at the same level, skills and doing same work, with equal compensation.When you job leveling do it really.

review.title: “Wolters Kluwer - big bureaucracy with people not really speaking to each other”
review.pros: Pros – - Generous compensation and time off - Some good managers
review.cons: Cons – - Benefits very low compared to others - Acquisitions and subsequent integrations not handled well - Miniscule promotions are handed out like candy, major job-changing promotions not so much
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Come down out of the towers and learn more about what makes your people happy and productive.

review.title: “Great products with a tangled brand/sales structure”
review.pros: Pros – Growing company with many business units that offer broad experience and geographic opportunities. The Amsterdam HQ does try to make sure all associates are updated. So they send out regular communications and expect the GMs to do the same. They do seem to try to present a balanced view of the business, with some challenges/bad news mixed in. They also have many opportunities to telecommute. The benefits are great and kick in quickly. The offices in NY are in Chelsea, right in the heart of all that is cool and hip. They also have opportunities/offices all over the US, so best bet is to just look at their jobsite for what is open at any moment in time.
review.cons: Cons – Structure of company is a bit cumbersome with business units competing for business against each other. This leads to a lot of frustration for the sales teams who find out from customer prospects that one sales rep from another branch is misinforming them about their product/service. Marketing strategy is very hard to develop as well since you are tripping up against the other WK service offerings. There was also for me a sense that the managers were working in isloation of each other, rather than getting a feeling that they all were pulling together with a common vision and goal. A bit of "every man for himself."
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Align products and services to customer groups. Stop confusing the customer with the many branches of Wolters Kluwer.

review.title: “Could be a rising star... or a bust.”
review.pros: Pros – As a business publisher, not a consumer driven org WK has tremendous opportunity. The potential for out of the box growth and personal contributions is high IF you land in an area where the executive team has political clout. Many of the publishing areas are mature, but have solid business plans to reach sizable growth objectives. As an executive, there are opportunities to move among the divisions and find upward career growth through the talent management program.
review.cons: Cons – A company who lives in the shadow of the much larger competitors of Thomson and Elsevier but who COULD be more aggressive, creative, and agile than those other publishers. The Health division in particular is suffering from competitive envy. There they dont make a move before the rest of the industry. The executive team is self absorbed and lacks leadership /motivational skills. The Health division is a hive of political connections and entitlements. There is constant misdirection and sleight of hand by the division execs who are caught up in fads and misplaced priorities -- like the unhealthy obsession with Six Sigma, without a real sense of its value or purpose.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Focus! Stop trying to be the "next big thing" and earn your way to a lead position with content by embracing the inherant strength of the staff and the wealth of knowledge held by the business units' management.

review.title: “Where has this company been all my life?”
review.pros: Pros – There is plenty of room for growth potential and advancement. If you want to learn and are eager and willing then this is the place to be.
review.cons: Cons – This is a team environment. If you are not a team player and have no interest in rising above your current status, then this is not the place for you.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep up the good work.

review.title: “Summation is a great place to work if you like to get paid for doing nothing”
review.pros: Pros – Flexiblity, easy to get a job, area the HQ is in, free Thursday lunches, you can sit around and do nothing and make a salary.
review.cons: Cons – Incompetent Sr. Management, Sr. management has no industry experience and do nothing all day
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – QUIT!Learn the product, learn the industry,learn how to manage your employees

review.title: “Lots of opportunity for experience, but poor pay”
review.pros: Pros – Nice office building with relatively good facilitiesStarting to be quite innovativeLots of support for mothers returning to workNice staff
review.cons: Cons – Rubbish payBehind the times on some thingsNot enough opportunity for career progression
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Pay staff on the ground more.

review.title: “Not worth working here”
review.pros: Pros – You will be working in regulatory reporting solutions as regulatory space is catching up fast these days in financial services industry
review.cons: Cons – 1) They hired many experienced ppl w/o even knowing where to fit them in the organization.2) They show you all sort of benefits while joining, but once you join you don't get what you are promised. Ex: Bonus payout was promised by HR it is 95% almost all the time, where as it only 50%.3) They hire experienced ppl of more than 6-7 yrs as Business analyst and make them work as technical analyst.As most ppl over here are from banks, they don't know what is the role of business analyst so they make undue advantage of it.4) Mgmt over here don't know how to handle customer issues. They just dump on you and expect you to do by end of day even if they assign you the issue at 6.30pm.5) If you are hired as associate business analyst then you will be good for nothing. You will doing data entry job in their reporting platform.6) They make you variable pay look big but actually you will get peanuts in terms of variable pay.7) NO customer interaction or travel opportunities at customer place.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – 1) hire those ppl who have some qualification to be at top management, instead taking ppl who have relatives over here in comp.2) Define role and responsibilities and hire those who can fit in the organization structure and explain the same to new ppl joining the comp.3) Stop taking ppl from banks , ultimately this is a s/w product based company.

review.title: “Professional Slave”
review.pros: Pros – It's a great place when it comes to the work life balance and flexibility. It is also a good start pay for the new graduates.
review.cons: Cons – Nothing here is good besides the flexibility:- Management invest more on systems than they do on the employees- Budget is the only issue they are concerned about- Everything is tried to be globalised forgetting the local culture- The managers never concerned about the grassroots and only act upon as they are told- All tals and no action on improvement of quality for employees- The annual increment is less than 2% and bonus is a laughing matter- We are a shared services but the profit made overseas is not shared locally for our efforts- The local director has their own goals and aims and is so self-centered- Environment is more silent than a cemetary- There is no value to employees - kick you when not needed
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Don't just speak to the director and manager. Have a skip level conversation with us grassroots to have a better picture. WK is well known globally but we in Asia are treated like slaves.

review.title: “Nice working atmosphere, a bit disorganised at times but good overall.”
review.pros: Pros – Supportive middle management, team spirit, good atmosphere, good benefits, responsiveness.
review.cons: Cons – Totally absurd and arbitrary business decisions take place that don't really benefit the business in any way but affects the employees in a personal level.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Employees are human beings, not just mere commodities.

review.title: “Good”

review.cons: Cons – Office location is not good. Have to face heavy traffic.
review.advice-to-management: Yes, I would recommend this company to a friend

review.title: “If you're looking to do the bare minimum, this is the place for you”
review.pros: Pros – Location right by Sheppard Subway Station. Lots of opportunity to get hands-on experience with duties/responsibilities outside of your role's scope. For the most part, friendly peer co-workers.
review.cons: Cons – Terrible upper management. U.S. doesn't care about Canadian operations because revenues are too small. Oblivious, bullying, mentally checked-out VP on the legal and business side--rampant favoritism not based in actual achievement. No future for the industry and no new ideas. Leadership vision and lack of execution is the most serious problem here. No willingness to invest time and resources in proper, thorough research to validate new product ideas.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – If serious about maintaining brand presence in Canada in the legal and business markets, get rid of VP. If not serious, save yourself the headache of running a non-profit and phase out business to save everyone the headache of working here

review.title: “VERY BAD WORK EXPERIENCE- unpleasant place to work for”
review.pros: Pros – - working from home-access to numerous financial, legal, tax resources
review.cons: Cons – - very bad employee morale (employees always concerned about getting fired)- negative office environment- bad/borderline abrasive management-roles very badly defined
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – -treat employees with respect and boost employee morale- threatening employees is not a way to improve work performance-ensure that employees are managed by people who understand their job duties and can provide actual support-separate technical specialists from sale specialists-ensure software developed properly before entering sales cycle-try to eliminate behind closed door bad talk about employees (word gets around)-ensure that office bullies are eliminated from the organization (creates toxic environment)

review.cons: Cons – salary not that great, they want best people at the lowest package. Deferred payment of more than 50k which you get at year completion.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – If you wish to retain people, pay them well

review.title: “Good company for new starters”

review.cons: Cons – *the management system is not very good
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – *take care of your employees, and consider their opinion

review.title: “YIKES!”
review.pros: Pros – Very good benefits, good bonus, good time off policy, good co-worker atmosphere. Can just do your job and be here forever....
review.cons: Cons – Some of the poorest management I've experienced in my career! CYA management philosophy from the 1950s. Don't EVER rock the boat.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Time to shake up the senior staff and let those with new and modern approaches clean the place up. Please walk the talk about values instead of sweeping issues under the carpet - you can't hide the incompentent forever.

review.title: “Great people, international environment”
review.pros: Pros – Great mission - what Wolters Kluwer does really contributes to makng the world a better place, by helping professionals. The people are generally really professional, intelligent, and team oriented - overall nice to work with. Being part of an international organization. Focus on innovation and using the latest technologies to create the best products. Movement for growth - I have felt very supported in my career aspirations and growth. CEO Nancy McKinstry is an inspiration - she really came up from within the organization (started in sales!). Great gender diversity - 2 of 4 of the the globaldivisions are headed by women.
review.cons: Cons – Culture isn't consistant across business units. Internal technologies are not super streamlined and modern. Leadership programs are not yet rolled out for lower management groups - only senior execs - but this is supposed to be changing in 2013/2014.
review.advice-to-management: Yes, I would recommend this company to a friend – I'm optimistic about the outlook for this company

review.title: “Good compensation when you get hired”

review.cons: Cons – - less salary raise than other companies offer- no career opportunities- after a time it gets boring, you work on the same 1-2 projects

review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Open your eyes, get out of the illusion that everything is fine.Start making decisions before its too late.There is difference between optimistic and over optimistic

review.cons: Cons – Large company, too diverse, often changes of CEO, lastly who didn't understand the worth of their people or understand what is happening outside of the US, just interested in the bottom line and ultimately their own career advancement. I got a thank you present for 6 years service swiftly followed by a call to tell me I was redundant ... One hand doesn't know what the other is doing.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Take time and card to value your people, the heroes that have propped you up and have valuable business knowledge. Ensure you don't become US centric.

review.title: “Great”
review.pros: Pros – Great people and great company
review.cons: Cons – Salary is not too great
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – conduct more reviews for contract staff

review.title: “Okay”
review.pros: Pros – Great environment. Excellent teamwork. Really good pay, especially for fresh grads. Flexible working hours.
review.cons: Cons – If you're applying for the sub-editor role: think again. Being a sub-editor is a skill and your 'skill' will be constantly tested during their probation period, which is 6 months. Other than meeting their standards in these 6 months, there is no job security whatsoever. If you don't reach the standards, and they don't think you will, you will get the boot. Unnecessary pressure. Work has to be absolutely perfect during the probation period. No open communication between the team who reviews your work and you. Good luck in keeping your sanity.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Stop treating your employees as educated labour workers. Without space for mistakes, the pressure will only deter new employees from performing well consistently.

review.title: “Chaotic due to poor managment choices”

review.cons: Cons – Job security lacking. Spread too thin trying to keep to many products going resulting in all products being mediocre. Upper management has not chosen under managers who are dedicated to the company or products resulting in bad management of those under them and poor plans and decisions for the future. Will have to divest some products (along with cutting jobs) to regain focus on the few successful products they have. Employees are the first to suffer from lack of focus because raises and profit sharing (for nonmanagement at least) are regularly not given due to "poor economy"
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Reevaluate your managers and make sure they are dedicated to the company and it products rather than spreading themselves between several pursuits. Get rid of products that are losing money and pulling the entire company down.

review.title: “Provides challenges - can be slow moving”

review.cons: Cons – LImited opportunities for growthClash of European vs US cultureNo game changer - rather follower
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Do more to retain your talented peoplePromote innovation further

review.pros: Pros – Flexible Environment, Work/Life Balance,CCH is a great Place to work, Lot to learn & People are very nice.
review.cons: Cons – Insecurity of job, Salary is not as per market standards.

review.title: “Was a good ride”

review.cons: Cons – Needs to do more research in customer needs before releasing solutions. Quality control needs to be improved upon in all software platforms.

Zero recognition of high performers - do exceptionally well (beyond job requirements) and it's what they pay you for; fall short (even for reasons beyond your control) and your head rolls. The supposedly prestigious "Wall of Fame" is practically a popularity contest; winning it gets you a puny voucher, and then it's back to work. Many employees who keep things running smoothly day in, day out go unnoticed and unrewarded.2. Bleak advancement prospects - it's basically a dead-end job environment unless you're looking to go into corporate management, and even then the opportunity to advance only comes up when someone resigns or gets promoted. And even then, some openings are directly given with a pretend advertisement for applicants.3. Non-existent salary increases - salary gets raised by less than 2% yearly, no matter how long you've been here or how good you are at your job. If it gets raised, that is.4. Poor management - one former HR consultant aptly put it: "Management will basically treat you like factory workers." Retention is non-existent on the management's agenda. They prefer to hire cheap fresh grads rather than retain experienced staff by increasing rewards and recognitions.5. Immature managers - a lot of people leave due to a small number of immature managers who were never meant to manage people. Among known issues are pushing for too much output from too few employees, playing yes-person to editorial and expecting high performance from over-worked staff. Until the powers that be deal with this issue, turnover will never drop.6. Meaningless surveys - there are a lot of surveys every year on workplace issues, employee happiness, etc, but constantly raised issues are never addressed year in, year out. Employees give a lot of feedback that are not acted upon. The jaded cynics are those who've been here for a few years - the optimistic and happy are usually fresh grads happy to have a job.7. Reluctance to invest - the company is always trying to make do with what it's got despite constantly trying to grow it's market (read: workload for staff). As a result, current employees are always seeing more and more workload, without a similar increase in pay or benefits.8. Unrealistic expectations - many new hires are given a strict period for learning the ropes, disregarding the human factor that leads to different learning abilities. Some of the best current employees (hired before the strict confirmation conditions were in place) took much longer to become good at what they do.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Talk to the people at the bottom, especially in Production, and find out what's making them want to leave, then deal with the issues.For every resigning employee, there are two who are actively job-hunting.

review.pros: Pros – Good compensation and benefits for the sales staff. Most products offer great content. Lots of PTO available even for new employees. Great people to work with. Product prices are OK, but could be more reasonable.
review.cons: Cons – Because CCH is owned by Wolters Kluwer, the company is a victim of constant budgetry cuts and decisions that don't relate to the real world. Frankly, if Wolters Kluwer were to leave CCH alone, it would probably be a better company to work for. However, CCH, like many companies these days, is being squeezed by a larger international company that is only looking out for the investors and not the interests of the employees or the customers. Mid level managers are not telling high level managers the truth about what's really going on with the company on the front lines. It is the classic left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing. The sales department in particular is in constant disray because CCH constantly reorganizes its database when it comes to assigning accounts to sales people. Customers fall through the cracks. Long-term customer rapport and relationships are lost because accounts are constantly reassigned by some cookie cutter approach cooked up by a Wolters Kluwer employee in the Netherlands who has no idea what sales is really about. One minute retention is important and the next minute new sales is the new flavor of the month. The company needs to equally focus on both retention and new sales. CCH needs to spend less time acquiring new companies and more time working with the employees and products they already have acquired over the years. Employees are dragged into too many meetings and bombarded with too many internal meaningless e-mails. Each department appears to be going into different directions based on its respectively compensation packages rather than the overall good of the employees, customers or the company in general. A decision in one department can adversely affect the performance of another department with little notice or warning. The company has a lot of potential, but keeps shooting itself in the foot.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – You claim in a recent press release that CCH is customer focused. Saying you are customer focused is like Fox News constantly telling its viewers it is a fair and balance news company. Don't tell customers you are customer focused, just be customer focused. Stop changing and redesigning the sales department - just get back to basics with sales, customer relations and rapport. Rearranging the deck chairs of sinking ship doesn't stop the ship from sinking.
