review.cons: Cons – The pay is terribleNo opportunity for advancementCertain facilities managed by terrible managersOutdated management methodologiesAll 'stick', no 'carrot'.No employee career or improvement trainingEmployees treated as faceless, replaceable cogs.Short term fixes only. So much time is fighting fires, and none is spent preventing them.Annual "Merit Increases" are pegged to a facility average (3.0) so there is no ability to be rewarded for performing well.Some facility managers skew reviews down, apparently believing that there is no such thing as a 5 and that 4 would be something like curing cancer (on a 1-5 scale).Concept of employee freedom foreign to facility management.No communication between facilities. Different departments rarely know what the other is doing.Unreasonable, sometimes mathmatically impossible goals/deadlines/service levels.A strong tendency towards presenting good metrics, instead of actually doing things right.Poorly designed/engineered facilities.Management makes promises it either can't or doesn't intend to deliver.Due, in part, to directives and culture from WK Intl, it is incredibly hard to increase headcount, even when all evidence indicates that a group is very understaffed.Little investment in future.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Insure that those running facilities have not set up their own kingdoms. Review, holistically, pay scales, job requirements, and such. Come to an understanding that there are deep problems within the organization and that it will take time and money to correct them. Invest in long term solutions, not quick fixes.

review.title: “False hope from upper management for a better workplace environment”
review.pros: Pros – Benefits – GreatPTO – More than other companiesPaid Company Holidays – More than other companiesCompany Discounts
review.cons: Cons – Management is unresponsiveVery little positive reinforcementLack of infrastructure (the left hand never knows what the right hand is doing)False hope from upper management for a better workplace environmentMeaningless surveys (you receive a survey, complete a survey, have a town hall and it is all “just talk” or an idea with no follow through)Ideas are never properly communicated
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Listen to the employees or trends. If an office has a lot of resignations then ask why. Employees resigned due to current management (my guess is they are still there and they were never dealt with) and salary (do the new replacement employees make more? a lot more? are they worth it????) .

review.title: “Excellent company to work for”
review.pros: Pros – You can do what you feel you need to do to achieve the key company goals; Open Environment; Allows Individual creativity and focussed energy; great interactions with manager;
review.cons: Cons – European company; not much knowledge sharing about Europe
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Build more interaction between operating groups

review.title: “Unrewardin”
review.pros: Pros – Some business units perform well
review.cons: Cons – Poor senior management. No vision doesn,t value employees
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Tune in

review.title: “Good for a short stop if you need a job, otherwise look for better opportunities”
review.pros: Pros – Some hardworking, well intentioned people at mid, lower levels. Commute is OK if the office is nearby.
review.cons: Cons – Sr. management has shown little vision or results in running the business. One of the larger divisions (which includes PCi) is run by an entrepreneur who build a $35 million rev business, sold it to WK big $, and then stayed on to run the business. He was promoted to run other businesses, which is a joke. He has no feel into the other business units, manages by intimidation because he fires people on a whim if they disagree with him on points. He keeps a small team of loyal people around him who 'yes' him to death, and tell him he is the greatest. He has never run a business other than his own since he left business school, and it shows. Most people ask why he hasn't taken his money and left, but he probably stays on because he makes more than anyone else would surely pay him. His HR 'business partner' team is a joke, mainly interested in making sure they avoid lawsuits from disgruntled and poorly treated former employees.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Invest in your products. Remove incompetent senior management.

review.title: “WK has the potential to be a great place to work if they changed executive management”
review.pros: Pros – well compensated compared with other companies in similar industriesintelligent co-workers, they hire smart people but don't fully utilize theminternational organization - opportunity to travel if that appealsbrand name recognition products make the products easy to sell whcih helps
review.cons: Cons – totally dissrespectful senior management staffloyalty is one sided - expect a lotlack of work life balance especially in sales
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – too many divisions and product lines make it difficult for customers. Also there is an incestuousness in how they move CEOs from one division to another - regardless of their ability or knowledge of the markets they serve. It has had disastrous results

review.title: “Quality Medical Publishing”
review.pros: Pros – Dedicated people doing excellent work. High standards and well-respected in the field. Up-to-date information. A good jump-start into medical publishing.
review.cons: Cons – Long hours. Multiple office locations. High level decisions don't necessarily consider mid-level recommendations. Inequitable salaries. High turnover at lower level.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The people at the bottom level are the ones who tow the line. They work extremely hard. Their knowledge is key.

review.title: “Stable place to work, however, little room for advancement”
review.pros: Pros – Friendly and helpful staff. good amount of time off, and decent benefits
review.cons: Cons – Very little room for growth. Not many real promotions (most promotions are just added responsibility with the possibility of a small salary increase). SOP's seem to change regularly, so its hard to be truly efficient at your position.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Develop a good "game plan" and let your staff become great at it, as opposed to changing it up every month. Give your long term employees incentive to stick around, not all talent needs to be found outside the company.

review.title: “Bad for contractors”
review.pros: Pros – Well known, stable company, decent compensation
review.cons: Cons – Siloed departments, poor communication across management levels
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Take a closer look at middle management performance

review.title: “Reasonable benefits. Low compensation. Deadend Career”
review.pros: Pros – Reasonable benefit package. Stable company with reasonable job security.
review.cons: Cons – Compensation is low and non-competitive. Way below market rate. No significant improvement after speaking with my manager. No promotion what-so-ever for 8 years.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Review compensation regularly and make sure the pay scale is competitive. Provide career roadmap and review for promotion regularly.

review.title: “lip service”
review.pros: Pros – good pto, better than average insurance costs
review.cons: Cons – very poor HR, director management
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – stop saying things you do not follow thru on.

review.title: “The best company to work for 7 years ago”
review.pros: Pros – Lots of potential, ideas are on the right track towards a brighter future.
review.cons: Cons – Projects are a mess. It's very good on paper as the company are hiring a lot of Business Analysts to do the job. 70% = 100% completed + a brand new project for the 30%.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Look at the documents but please do realize that the company has not moved from where it was a year ago. Less BAs more real workers please, no more BS.

review.title: “Good people trying to do well within limits of new customer online interface”
review.pros: Pros – Good reputation in industry, strong product development, editorial support for sales force and customers..Sales leadership is generally upfront about direction of business and goals.Company strives to make sure that related business units work in partnership.While not well accepted by community new information platform is striving to offer tools and features that will become the "standard" for the future and all WK business units worldwide
review.cons: Cons – Sales goals difficult to attain due to unpopular internet platform.Platform roll out pushed to customers before it was ready.Sales force was not appraised of key features that did not work well compared to old platform. Had to learn from customer comments and experiments.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Better involvement of all channels prior to roll out of research platform. Be upfront on what the shortcomings are. Make sure there is more involvement from wide range of internal customers before next major system changes are rolled out.

review.title: “Great PTO, Relaxed environment.. Mediocre pay at IT Quality Technician 1 job.”
review.pros: Pros – You get 4 weeks of paid time off immediately (balance accrues through first year)It is a relaxed environment for the most part.You are generally allowed to work autonomously.
review.cons: Cons – Entry level quality assurance pay is mediocre. Once you promote to Senior or higher you will get paid just fine. It is unfortunate they chose to do this.Performance is not always rewarded as you would hope.Merit raises are lumped into a pool. (meaning if your department is bad you won't get much of a raise even if you substantially outperform your peers)
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Merit raises should be based on individual merit. People cannot force their peers to do better. They have no control. Please figure this concept out as I'm sure your raises are based on your performance and not the collective performance of all the people in your same roll world wide.

review.title: “slowly getting the corporate head out of the sand...”
review.pros: Pros – Great reputation within the publishing industry and respect of customers. Low pressure environment and relatively clear job responsibilities. Flexible hours and work-from-home contribute to health work/life balance. Strong benefits. Pleasant work environment and friendly atmosphere. Mostly qualified employees and managers.
review.cons: Cons – Extremely poor intra-company communication. The proverbial left hand has NO idea what the right hand is doing, which contributes to duplication of efforts and working in a vacuum. Very slow in accepting and adapting to the advent of electronic and interactive media - people don't want to buy $300 textbooks any more! Starting to venture into new media and e-formats, but the train has left the station. Detached (and mostly invisible) senior management and preference given to publishing "insiders".
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Wake up and put some real resources towards modernizing product line and marketing techniques. Spend more time in the office so you have a presence that might inspire some confidence in your leadership.

review.title: “Good place to work as long as you are comfortable dealing with ambiguity!”
review.pros: Pros – Good balance of work and life combined with good opportunitiews for interesting work.
review.cons: Cons – The constantly changing priorities makes WKUK a very frustrating place to work. Once you have worked out the best strategy try and ensure you communicate this to the wider teams and stick to it.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Work out what you want to be the best at!

review.title: “Great place, nice people”
review.pros: Pros – They are fair, not micro managing, and the benefits and salary are fair for what I do.
review.cons: Cons – none I am very happy
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Stop with all the latest and greatest time wasters like Six Sigma, and they love Corporate BS words. Too top heavy

review.title: “My thoughts on CCH-SFS”
review.pros: Pros – Good benefits, new work environment, challenging work, friendly people, access to corporate discounts and other benefits that come with working for a large global company.
review.cons: Cons – Low pay for rank and file compared to other businesses, too much work with too few people, transition of making one company from two.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Stop saving nickels and dimes on the backs of your employees

review.title: “Not for Me”
review.pros: Pros – Great sales people and team members that really know their stuff.
review.cons: Cons – Poor mid-level leadership but many are no longer with the company.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Value your people...really.

review.title: “Used to be great”
review.pros: Pros – Everyone below the Senior Management level is hardworking, dedicated and very competent. Lots of knowledgeable people who really want to do an outstanding job.
review.cons: Cons – The Executive Management is focused only on looking good for the analysts, regardless of whether those are intelligent long-term business decisions.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Wise up! Stop believing your own press releases!! You might be able to snow the analysts, but the customers will vote with their feet.

review.title: “Good place to work”
review.pros: Pros – Great hoursGreat productGood pay and benefits
review.cons: Cons – Lots of travel, large territoryMy role was constantly changing
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Spend more time in the field with your reps.

review.title: “Good benefits, good people, below average pay, very little room for advancement, very little money for training”
review.pros: Pros – People, time off, very few weeks over 40 hours, low stress.
review.cons: Cons – Below average wages, no money invested in training employees, little room to advance, tendency to fall behind in pay if you're there for a number of years, Senior management strongly believes that off-shoring and outsourcing save money, when in fact the numbers just don't add up. As with most companies, there is very little value placed on experience and business knowledge. Employees are not replaced as they leave. Instead, other employees share the burden or the work is sent to India. Middle management understands the pros and cons to outsourcing but has little say and no guts. Offshore and onsite consultants come and go. So much time is wasted on bringing new ones up to speed. These consultants are very young and entry level and are not gurus. Senior management perceives full-timers as replaceable and less skilled than their offshore counterparts - though in reality the opposite is true.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Senior management - listen to your middle managers. They have a ton of insight but very little gall. In this era of little job security, no one wants to make waves. Outsourcing works well for some things but very poorly for others, and you need to recognize when it just doesn't work.

review.title: “Stay away! Toxic environment and getting worse!”
review.pros: Pros – There is some flexibility when it comes to work life balance.
review.cons: Cons – This company at one point had the potential to be ok. But the yelling, the attempt at intimidation, the lack of respect for employees, and executive leadership that is incompetent, will lead them to complete demise unless the President and CEO is fired and new leadership comes in and brings in an entirely new executive team. There is simply no other way. They cut and cut and cut to get to numbers they want to report, with no strategic plan for growth and everything has suffered with no end in sight. Marketing and Innovation the true cornerstones of a growing company are non existent, and completely unsupported. Product management blames sales for not selling the product, this has been going on for 5 years, and sales has changed so many times and new strategies attempted, guess what? It's not sales THE PRODUCTS SUCK! If you were producing things the market wanted they would buy, how simple is that? If you want to be frustrated, lied to, not given respect for the experience you bring to the table and be part of a failing company join Wolters Kluwer Financial services. You will wake up every day hating your life until the day you get out.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Fire the executive team and start over. It's time.

review.title: “Good company but difficult industry.”
review.pros: Pros – Great vacation (4 weeks) and good work-life balance. Management good about your taking pto as long as work is done. International conglomerate - Wolters Kluwer- provides potential for world-wide opportunities. Fascinating and worthwhile industry (medical information services/publishing).
review.cons: Cons – Difficult industry for successful career. Head office in Philadelphia - Maryland offices are now only satellite offices as compared to a few years ago. Huge company with large company mindset. No career paths or mentors.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Provide career paths and mentoring

review.title: “Stay away from this place”
review.pros: Pros – -Some wonderful folks work in Wolters kluwer. The company is very flexible about working from home. Benefits and salary is reasonable but the good points are overshadowed by the cons.
review.cons: Cons – The attitude of Senior management to the staff is horrible. Long hours and constantly micro managed. Politics is rife as a small circle of management try to beat each other and their staff up trying to climb the corporate ladder. Feedback is never listened to and any sort of praise never happens. The majority of decisions come from the US these days and the attitude towards non US based employees is really bad. The technology is years behind and the infrastructure is falling apart. Overall the worst company by far in my entire career.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Stop treating your employees so badly, this is not the 1800's. For goodness sake give some attention to the IT infrastructure

review.title: “Good & Bad”
review.pros: Pros – This is an exciting time to be working in the publishing industry as they are challenged to keep up with competition to move to on line delivery platforms (vs. hard copy); new level of required skill sets and a different go to market requirements
review.cons: Cons – Hierarchical management; low morale; slow to move; stuck in some old ways of doing things
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Quickly leverage the new way of doing business and managing and make it the DNA of work life at WK;

review.title: “Wolters Kluwer US”
review.pros: Pros – The executive leadership of Wolters Kluwer have developed a sound strategy for maintaining or attaining lead positions within the various markets in which it competes.
review.cons: Cons – Multiple staff reductions over the past few years has left remaining staff accountable for more responsibilities than can be maintained at prior levels of quality and competency. However the company has begun to rebuild staff numbers with new hires better suited to the changing work.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep the current division executive leaders in place for longer than 18 months to provide much needed stability and continuity. They are doing a good job and employees want to execute for them.

review.title: “Nice place if you want to be retired in place.”
review.pros: Pros – Lifestyle, very nice people. Easy to be a standout
review.cons: Cons – Too many holdovers from publishing days that were skilled and compotent but need to move on and retire with grace and aplomb.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – let the cream rise to the top.

review.title: “Hard to get work done due to internal dynamics and bureaucracy.”
review.pros: Pros – 5bn$ company, good products in the Information Services space, significant acquisitions. The Financial Services arm is better than the others in terms of working environment.
review.cons: Cons – Lot of internal dynamics, Very hard to get good work done, Autocratic management style, Very little positive reinforcement when doing a good job, Lack of infrastructure, Steady layoffs as a result of offshore initiative. Acquired organizations have not integrated well into the company resulting in a lot of intra-unit politicking. There is no clarity on roles & responsibilities of acquired units. Each acquired unit has its own culture, including a widely differing holiday schedule. Not much in the way of processes. Chicago downtown office lacks basic facilities & infrastructure. Incompetent IT Support services vendor (outsourced) takes ages to resolve minor issues.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Management needs to cultivate a spirit of bon homie within the company by using a mix of carrot and the stick instead of using the stick all the time. Spend more time on redefining & streamlining processes instead of micro-managing operations.

review.title: “no room to advance”
review.pros: Pros – vacation timecasual dressfriendly work environment
review.cons: Cons – performance reviews don't mean anything, people are promoted by years of service not quality of workhigher ups constantly changing whats important with the companylack of good leadershipno effort to help employees succeed and plan career path within company
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – better access managers and what they are doing to get the most out of their employees.old school mentality, need to allow people to think outside the box.team environment or individual success? which do they value and want?

review.title: “If you have an option, take it”
review.pros: Pros – Gain breadth of experience in health care information technologies, epecially if you are interested in health care content "construction" and "distribution"
review.cons: Cons – Thinks like a publishing company. Expectations from health care information technology vendors are high, wolters kluwer health does not cut it. Its senior management made decisions as if it was a publishing company while it tried to company while competing in fast-changing health care information technology space.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Wake up. World is changing! Or should I say, it has changed. Get new toolkit and train your employees on it before they leave you ... or before you are forced to let them go.

review.title: “CT”
review.pros: Pros – - Great PTO policy - start out with 20 days of PTO for first year - Quarterly bonus - Many benefits
review.cons: Cons – - No advancement in career - Many people in key spots are not monitored and only got there by putting enough time in
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Encourage your employees to grow and don't hold people back. Many people are held back from advancement b/c the company only thinks of themself and not advancement for the company

review.title: “If you love getting paid for very little work, this is a great place.”
review.pros: Pros – Very laid back, great benefits, easy-going management, good locations, easy work
review.cons: Cons – Too lax management, don't seem to care what you do, inadequate communications and training. Managemen isn't around and leaves everything up to you. They have people there that truly do not care about their jobs but collecting checks and they are never let go. You can literally come and go as you please, no one is watching anything you do. In effect, you learn nothing but how to get by on someone else's watch.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Communicate with employees, give direction and support

review.title: “Wolters Kluwer”
review.pros: Pros – A pro is paid time off.
review.cons: Cons – A con is the culture.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Improve management.

review.title: “Good benefit package except expensive health insurance option. Expected to work 60-80 hours per week for few months.”
review.pros: Pros – Benefit package - a lot of PTO if you are allowed to take them all and profile sharing plan is one of the highlight. Your hard work may be rewarded by nominate to attend achievement club which can spend few days vacation on company's expense.
review.cons: Cons – You will expect to have long hours of work and stressful work environment. Management may put you in panic mode intentionally so you can get the job done quicker and burn you out quicker. Many newly hired managers are clueless - as long as you know how to play politic, you can be in management team. Always has excellent process on paper to improve work but never get executed or interpreted correctly.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Don't be afraid to fire incompetent employees and really try to reward outstanding employees. Do rather than talk. (Less meeting and more actual work)

review.title: “Good place to work if you never want to do anything different - ever..”
review.pros: Pros – Good benefitsGood payLots of training and resources available
review.cons: Cons – Lack of promotion opportunity. Each year you ask for a promotion, you will be given a list of what needs to be done to get there. Then, once you have completed those things nothing will happen, and when your review comes around (and you ask about a promotion once again) you will be given a new list of things you need to accomplish first. Even if you routinely outperform the vast majority of others in your position.Upper management short-sightedness. More and more over the last few years the company has been moving with the new trend to make things look pretty in the very, very, short term scenario. Even if those strategies are detrimental to the future."Flavor of the Month" mentality. Whatever is the chosen product of the moment (usually one that was poorly planned, implemented, and rolled out by the company and is not doing well as a result) is, if it is not doing well it is blamed on the front line. Your desk can be raking in revenue, but if "x" number of your clients haven't gotten on board with "insert chosen product here", you might as well be invisible.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – CT used to value their employees and have success with a philosophy of hiring talented people, providing them with the right resources, keeping them happy, and then letting them do their jobs. Having quality, well trained, motivated employees that aren't weighed down by micro-management, complicated compensation packages, lack of recognition for "big picture" success, and lack of management support is what resulted in a high quality service product to the client.Less games and frills and more focus on the big picture and the value of quality employees that are kept happy.

review.title: “Wolters Kluwer”
review.pros: Pros – The organization is a great company to work for, and I would recommend working here to anyone. They do offer a goo work/life balance.
review.cons: Cons – There is not much opportunity for growth and development. They did not seem to embrace change well, and management communication was difficult.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – The organization is strong and has a lot to offer to employees, but needs to work on inner workings of departments.

review.title: “Good experience, low salary”
review.pros: Pros – Managers provided many opportunities to staff for small advancements and chances to take on increasing responsibility. A lot can be learned about publishing from working at such a large company. Also, the work-life balance was great: I was never expected to work evenings or weekends.
review.cons: Cons – It's a problem in most of publishing, but editorial salaries were low as compared with many other industries. It could have taken 10 years to achieve a significantly higher paying position, and I wasn't allowed to work overtime.
review.advice-to-management: Advice to Senior Management – Keep giving lower-level employees opportunities to lead and to increase their level of responsibility, but allow better salary increases for those who are talented and willing to put in extra hours.
